WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The rice radical and rice are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This also refers to "America," maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Aren't radicals nice? They make things so much easier... if you've been studying them.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You've got tons of dry grains of rice. You have no idea what you're going to do with it. Then, you come up with a solution. All this dry rice could go towards filling up the bay („Åπ„ÅÑ), so you have more land to farm on!
WaniKani_Reading_Info: In your mind, bulldoze the rice into the bay, watching it fill it up, then pile high. It's not particularly good looking land, but it'll do, and it's already full of seeds, so that's pretty good. The important thing is that you think you have way too much of the stuff, so the only way to get rid of it is to dump it in a large body of water, and that large body of water is a bay.

humanum_full_description_en:
" Rice " refers to grains of rice with the hull removed. "Zhou Li. Land official. "Sheren": "The entry and exit of the palm of the millet, distinguish the objects." Jia Gongyan: "Among the nine grains, millet, millet, rice, beam, melon, and soybeans, all six have rice, hemp and adzuki beans, wheat, three There is no rice, so it is said that "nine valleys and six meters"." Sun Yi asked justice: "The one that has been pounded is rice, and the one that has not been pounded is millet."

In ancient times, "mice" meant not only rice and millet, but also grain. The ancients pounded or peeled the grains, the fruit inside was called " rice ", and the unpeeled was called " su ". "Shuowen": "Rice, millet. It resembles the shape of heshi. All rice belongs to rice." Now people still call "peanut kernels" as "peanuts", that is, the peanuts have their shells removed. Xu Jie's "Girl's Lesson": "After the fight, I will use peanuts to coax her."

There are three small dots (‚óé) on the top and bottom of the Jia Jin inscription, one painting in the middle, the small dots are like rice grains, and the middle painting Li Xiaoding thinks that it is like a sieve (sieve) shape, and Bai Yuzheng thinks it is like the japonica rice of a grain of rice.

In addition to the original meaning of oracle bone inscriptions, which means rice, it is also pronounced "Êïâ", which means comfort and is also used as a sacrificial name. Clementine is mostly used as a clan name.

heisig_comment:
* As a primitive, it keeps its meaning of rice, and is meant to connote a very ordinary, commonplace grain, in contrast to the primitive for wheat that we just learned. (This meaning accords well with Japan, where the output of rice far exceeds that of wheat.)
It occasionally takes a different shape when it stands on its own, or is joined to a line above. In this case, we shall have it refer specifically to grains of rice. This primitive is not to be confused with the similar-looking primitive for water. While the stroke orders are nearly alike, grains of rice has 5 strokes, while water only has 4 because it joins the second and third strokes into one.
Finally, we may note that by itself the kanji for rice is an abbreviation used for the United States, which can then also serve as an alternate reading for the main primitive form, if you so wish.

* As a primitive, it keeps its meaning of rice, and is meant to connote a very ordinary, commonplace grain, in contrast to the primitive for wheat that we just learned. (This meaning accords well with Japan, where the output of rice far exceeds that of wheat.)
It occasionally takes a different shape when it stands on its own, or is joined to a line above. In this case, we shall have it refer specifically to grains of rice. This primitive is not to be confused with the similar-looking primitive for water. While the stroke orders are nearly alike, grains of rice has 5 strokes, while water only has 4 because it joins the second and third strokes into one.
Finally, we may note that by itself the kanji for rice is an abbreviation used for the United States, which can then also serve as an alternate reading for the main primitive form, if you so wish.

Meter
Basic explanation of words
Meter
m«ê
The name of the seeds of cereals or other plants peeled off: millet. Rice. Rice. Mizhu Xingui (rice is like a pearl; firewood is like a osmanthus, describing the high prices and difficult life).
The international unit of length (formerly known as "meter" and "meter"), one meter is equal to three city feet.
name.
Meter
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[‚ë†] [m«ê]
["Guangyun" Mo Liqie, top water chestnut, Ming. ]
(1) Peeled rice grains; especially peeled rice grains.
(2) The seeds of certain plants that have been peeled off.
(3) The rice-like embroidered patterns on the clothes of ancient nobles.
(4) Yu very little or very small amount. Still bit by bit.
(5) The main unit of length in the metric system. Formerly called Mitu or meter. One meter is divided into one hundred centimeters, and the city system is three feet.
(6) Last name. Tang Youmi Jiarong.

Radicals: Á±≥  (rice)
Meaning Mnemonic
The rice radical and rice are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This also refers to "America," maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
Aren't radicals nice? They make things so much easier... if you've been studying them.
Reading Mnemonic
You've got tons of dry grains of rice. You have no idea what you're going to do with it. Then, you come up with a solution. All this dry rice could go towards filling up the bay („Åπ„ÅÑ), so you have more land to farm on!
In your mind, bulldoze the rice into the bay, watching it fill it up, then pile high. It's not particularly good looking land, but it'll do, and it's already full of seeds, so that's pretty good. The important thing is that you think you have way too much of the stuff, so the only way to get rid of it is to dump it in a large body of water, and that large body of water is a bay.
